question_stem: The function g(x) is defined as \(g(x) = 2x^3 - 7\).  The function h(x) is defined as \(h(x) = g(x) + k\), where k is a constant. It is given that \(h(2) = 3\).

parts.solution_text: We are given \(h(x) = g(x) + k\) and \(h(2) = 3\).  Substituting \(x=2\) into \(g(x)\), we have \(g(2) = 2(2^3) - 7 = 2(8) - 7 = 16 - 7 = 9\).  Since \(h(x) = g(x) + k\), we have \(h(2) = g(2) + k\).  Substituting the given values, we get \(3 = 9 + k\).  Solving for \(k\), we find \(k = 3 - 9 = -6\).
